utterances: But he also talked about how when he was in the Army in World War II, he was stationed, I think it was somewhere in France.
And even though he wasn't a particularly good player, the other guys in his unit asked him to play.
And he got to play somewhere over in France.
And it was one of the most warm memories of his life, was playing this pickup game in the middle of nowhere with strangers, but getting to throw the ball around.
And so, I put that in the book as well.
This is an e-mail from Rich in Grants Pass, Oregon.
My memories go back to about 1963 when I delivered the daily newspaper to Mickey Mantle's home in Tenafly, New Jersey.
Fridays, I'd collect for the week.
Can you believe it was only 33 cents?
And his wife would sometimes call out for him to come and give me the weekly payment.
I would stand there in awe.
And occasionally, he would actually take me to his side yard and we toss a baseball back and forth for a short while.
He signed a ball for me: To my favorite newspaper boy.
Rick, I'm told that it's now worth $200,000 or more.
That would not be - I hope it's worth more than that to the writer of that note.
But I'm sure it is not worth that much.
But it's a priceless memory that certainly can't be sold, I would hope.
Let's talk with Cesar - Cesar with us from Kansas City.
How are you doing?
Okay.
A couple of things that has happened - they mentioned Findlay, Ohio.
And I went to school in Findlay, and they mentioned Roger Clemens.
And I happen to watch 1988 World Series with Roger Clemens in a restaurant, his favorite restaurant in (unintelligible), that's called Walahalla(ph) Mexican Restaurant.
So that very interesting to me, as I was listening to your talks about baseball.
I can talk baseball all day.
So I know that that's a very - a game dear to my heart.
But my biggest memory playing baseball was in 1977 watching my local team in (unintelligible) Mexico beat up on the De Diablo Rojo de Mexico in the championship game.
I was about - in '77, I was 8 years old, and it was a fond, fond memory for me.
I'll take your comments off the air.
Okay.
Thanks very much, Cesar.
Bye-bye.

There's a lot of - there's a story a little bit like that about an 8-year-old kid watching a game on television, the World Series in fact, and watching Roberto Clemente play - the great Puerto Rican player.
And this was a kid in Venezuela.
Yeah.
His name was Ozzie Guillen.
And Ozzie Guillen watched Roberto Clemente, and even though he was Venezuela and Roberto Clemente was from Puerto Rico, he was still such a hero.
This is, of course, before Clemente died tragically and became just a martyr for many things.
But Clemente was an incredible hero to all sorts of children, particularly in Latin America.
And Ozzie Guillen watched Clemente hit triples and hit homeruns and throw runners out from right field.
And he's like, I want to do that.
I want to play like that.
And Ozzie Guillen, of course, ended being a standout Major League shortstop for about 15 years, and then led the Chicago White Sox as their manager to the 2005 World Series Championships.
So it's that sort of connection of generations that I've tried to capture here as well.
There's a number of astonishing stories.
My favorite - we did not have time to get to and will not - is Terry Francona's story about his right fielder in Birmingham, Alabama - fellow by the name of Michael Jordan.
And the best story about that, by the way, is the time that Terry Francona and his right fielder play pickup basketball together.
That's right.
There was a very famous pickup basketball game in the Arizona Fall League back in 1994.
I was actually there for it, when Jordan just schooled everybody else.
Francona was there, and I let people watch as well.
There's a great story about that.
You'll have to read Alan's book to find out what it is, though, because we're out of time.
Alan, happy baseball season.
Thanks so much.
Good luck with the book.
Thank you very much, Neal.
Happy Opening Day everybody.
Alan's Schwarz is the author of ""Once Upon a Game: Baseball's Greatest Memory."" He's now a staff writer for The New York Times.
He joined us today from our bureau in New York.
I'm Neal Conan.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
In presidential elections even the smallest places have big impact.
That happened in the last two campaigns where huge Republican margins in rural areas helped overcome Democratic dominance of cities.
A new survey indicates rural voters are poised to play a big role again, but not in the way Republicans might expect.
NPR's Howard Berkes explains why.
The survey reveals a topsy-turvy body politick where some in the reddest counties on the political map are defying past behavior.
These are rural places President Bush won by double digits in 2000 and 2004.
But this year there are rural Republicans leaning Democratic, including Betsy Rowe, an attorney, college fundraiser and church-going mom in Pella, Iowa.
Normally I would consider myself a moderate Republican.
How did you vote in the last two presidential elections.
I voted Republican, but between Obama and McCain, I believe Obama has a better chance for bringing us together as a country.
There are also rural Democrats leaning Republican.
Mary Goshee(ph) is also a churchgoing mom and substitute teacher in Finley, Ohio, who voted for Barack Obama when living in Illinois, but she doesn't think she can do that now.
I've never even really thought I would ever vote for a Republican, but I just don't know if he really has the experience that I'm looking for.
He's such a fresh new face and, yes, change would be nice but we also need somebody who has a little more background.
Both Goshee and Rowe responded to the survey, which shows an even split if it's Hillary Clinton against John McCain.
That's a stunning upgrade for Clinton, who was as unpopular as illegal immigrants in a similar rural poll last year.
Many consider Barack Obama the likely Democratic nominee and he's nine points behind in a survey.
But that turns out to be bad news for Republican McCain, says Alan Abramowitz, a political scientist at Emory University.
The Republicans need to take a big polarity out from that vote.
I think they need more than a ten-point margin with rural voters if they're going to carry most of those swing states.
The survey was conducted last week in rural counties in 13 battleground states from Florida to New Hampshire and Pennsylvania to Nevada.
Close to 700 likely voters responded.
The Center for Rural Strategy sponsored the survey.
Questions about issues showed John McCain perceived as strong on values and weak on the economy, notes Bill Greener, a Republican political consultant involved in the survey.

The challenge is to continue to build upon the matter of values while at the same time demonstrating the ability to address and solve the economic challenges that confront rural America and indeed all Americans.
More than half of those surveyed agreed with the statement that Barack Obama does not share their values.
In the last two elections it was family and social values, issues like gay marriage and abortion and gun ownership, that motivated many rural voters to go Republican.
But in this election so far, gas prices, food costs and the economy loom as major issues.
Close to half of those surveyed in this rural poll agreed that John McCain does not understand their economic problems.
Alan Abramowitz of Emory University.
If the Democrats can't capitalize on that, particularly among these white working-class voters, they may as well pack up their bags and go home.
The poll indicates there's a potentially receptive audience among rural voters.
Close to half describe themselves as Democratic or leaning Democratic.
More than half describe themselves as moderate or liberal.
But there's a key question the survey doesn't answer, notes Anna Greenberg, the Democratic pollster who conducted the polling.

Is there a set of Democratic voters in rural areas who simply will not vote for Barack Obama because of his race or other issues, or once they know him better and understand how problematic John McCain is, can they be persuaded to vote for Barack Obama, and I think that's the big question.
The survey team plans to track these rural trends for both Democratic and Republican candidates in at least two more polls before the November election.
Howard Berkes, NPR News.
You can analyze this rural poll yourself by going to our Web site at NPR.org.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington.
Neal Conan is sick.
It's December, and that means party season is in full swing.
Holiday parties are supposed to be fun, occasions for good cheer and good will to all, but it doesn't always work that way.
Whether it's the obligatory office party or the family Christmas gathering, there's a host of party pitfalls to navigate.
How do you stay cool as your hostile mother-in-law criticizes everything from the eggnog to the table setting?
Or how do you gracefully retreat from one of those polite but uncomfortable conversations with the boss?
And don't forget the lecherous guest or the guest who's had too much to drink but doesn't know it.
Today we've invited some experts to help us survive the season.
Comedian Amy Sedaris has just written a book on the art of hostessing.
Steve Kleinedler, an editor at the ""American Heritage Dictionary"" has some advice on how to sound smart at your next event.
And advice columnist Amy Dickinson gives us the lowdown on mingling.
Later this hour, a massive search and rescue effort is underway in Oregon.
We'll talk about how these searches are conducted and what hikers and climbers should do if they get lost.
But first, surviving the holiday party.
Are you in the midst of planning a party or getting geared up to attend one?
What's your holiday dilemma?
Give us a call.
Our number here in Washington: 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
And our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
(Soundbite of doorbell)
18-year-old Tim Tatum is near the front of the line.
One of the things that I think I admired about Carly Fiorina is when she won the primary in California for U.S.
Senate, she didn't really do that traditional tacking to the middle.
Of course, that probably didn't help her in an overwhelmingly blue state like California, and Democrats turned Fiorina's core strength - her business record - into a liability with voters.
During a debate, Senator Boxer said Californians must choose whether to reelect her...
